Award.AwardTitle: Insight from Lamprey Genome: Investigations of the GnRH-GTH System
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will emphasize approaches to studying brain hormones and receptors that utilize new methodologies that are becoming available through the disciplines of hormonal genomics and proteomics, and presenting themselves through knowledge of basal vertebrate systems. Based on previous and present findings, this research will include novel studies using established techniques and developing complementary molecular techniques to, in part, increase the understanding and insight into the molecular and functional evolution of brain and pituitary hormones and receptors. The studies will focus on the molecular, biochemical and functional studies of brain gonadotropin releasing hormone and pituitary gonadotropins in lampreys to test the overall hypothesis that these hormones and their receptor(s) share common functional and developmental features compared to later evolved vertebrates. The research will examine the roles that modifications in interactive cellular networks, represented by genes and their products (hormones, receptors, and signaling molecules), have on biological function from the perspectives of molecular, cellular, and systems biology. This research has and will include graduate and undergraduate students who will be trained and involved in all aspects of this project. Outreach activities will include presentations to the general public at different kinds of forums such as the annual NH Sea Lamprey Appreciation Day as well as collaborations with investigators from other institutions. In addition, the PI and her laboratory will continue their collaborations with students and staff at New Hampshire Technical Community College (NHCTC) and students at UNH.

POR.DRECONTENT:
My outcomes, contributions and major breakthroughs are related to the origin, evolution and function of the neuroendocrine system in vertebrates. Our work showed and confirmed that the hypothalamic (brain)-pituitary system was a vertebrate innovation and seminal event that emerged prior to or during the differentiation of the ancestral agnathans (Sower et al., 2009). My laboratory along with my collaborators have been the driving force in elucidating the lamprey neuroendocrine system in the control of reproduction. 

The goal of my NSF research grant was to test the global hypothesis that lampreys and hagfish have a hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. We examined the roles that modifications in interactive cellular networks, represented by genes and their products (hormones, receptors, and signaling molecules), have on biological function from the perspectives of molecular, anatomical, cellular, and systems biology. The research during the  grant period involved the training of four graduate students, fourteen undergraduate students, and five postdoctoral/visiting scholars including nine from underrepresented groups. The outcomes of this grant led to nineteen full-refereed publications/book chapters and three in press. Fifteen of these publications have been co-authored by graduate students, postdoctoral associates and/or undergraduate students. The PI, postdocs, undergraduate and graduate students presented 38-invited symposium speaker & oral presentations and posters at various conferences.  Network activities included participating in the international lamprey genome project and collaborating with Great Bay Community College Biotechnology program. Outreach activities included several public lectures to various groups including the Audubon society, sponsoring three New York University students in making a Lamprey Documentary (released June 2013), and participating in the annual Statewide Lamprey Appreciation Day. In addition, Wayne Decatur (Postdoc) presented two workshops on Proteopedia at UNH and an international conference. The PI has served as symposium organizer and/or chair of four symposia at one national and three international conferences. The PI sponsored three New York University film students to produce a lamprey documentary video. Upon request, the PI has provided lamprey tissues, cDNA, hormone antisera and peptides to more than 16 investigators world-wide.
